decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with the details submitted pursuant to condition 3 under application reference 20/02857/CLC.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any windows or rooflights at first floor level or above in the northern (flank) or southern (flank) elevations (including the two side facing windows within the rear first floor bay) shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no windows shall be inserted nor any other openings formed (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) at first floor level or above in the in the northern (flank) or southern (flank) elevations of the dwelling unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no additions or enlargements to any dwellinghouse(s) on the site (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers and to safeguard the health and longevity of trees worthy of retention, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no detached buildings (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected on the site unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers and to safeguard the health and longevity of trees worthy of retention, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The rating level of the noise determined by the cumulative sound emissions of the plant to which this permission relates shall be at least 5dBA lower than the existing background noise level at any given time of operation. The noise levels shall be measured or predicted 1m externally to any window at the nearest residential facade and the measurements and assessment shall be made according to BS 4142:2014.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any external lighting installed at the site shall be angled so as to prevent any spillage or glare beyond the site's boundaries.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with "Tree Sruvey, Arboricultural Impact Assessment, Tree Constraints Plan, Arboricultural Method Statement and Tree Protection Plan" authored by Advanced Tree Services and dated March 2020. The approved measures shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work on site and maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with the landscaping scheme as shown on drawing PD - MLP - 001 Rev A. This scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with the details submitted pursuant to condition 14 under application reference 20/02857/CLC.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with the details submitted pursuant to condition 15 under application reference 20/02857/CLC.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The garaging or car parking shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard-bound, adequately-drained, dust-free surface prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained and kept free from obstruction thereafter. The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in accordance with the details submitted pursuant to condition 17 under application reference 20/02857/CLC.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.Consultations 2 responses received. One response raises concern re disruption during construction but supports the proposed development the other is in objection to the proposed development. The repsonses are summarised below and the matters raised are addressed through the officers assessment. - Effects on trees - Excessive height or bulk of buildings - Loss of light/Sunlight - Privacy - Unacceptable or incompatible use- Hours of construction- Noise - FumesRelevant History21/03643/HOU -- Erection of first floor rear and rear canopy extension. Installation of 1nos front rooflight. Alteration to fenestrations -- Permitted with conditionsAssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Other mattersDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is an amendment to the extant planning permission 21/03643/HOU. The amendments include- Omission of chimney and rear roof lights- Altered rear canopy design- Insertion of additional first floor window on east elevation- Solar panels on rear roof slopeIt is acknowledged that the proposed developmennt as did the extant planning permission 21/03643/HOU does not fully accord with the guiding principles of the Council's adopted Residential Design SPD. However it is considered in this instance in the context of the extant planning permissin and the site and its surroundings the proposed development would be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Given the orientation of the proposed development including the additions made to the extant planning permission it would pass the 45-degree plan test in relation to the closest habitable windows of the neighbouring properties, and as such it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.  Other mattersTreesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) states that The Council will expect new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders are not adversely affected. Policy Guidance 7 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) state that generally there will be a presumption against the loss of trees - regardless of whether they are protected by virtue of a Tree Preservation Order or with respect to their location within a designated Conservation Area.Officer Comment: Officers note that the area sits within a Tree Preservation Area Order, and given that the trees of concern would be sited an appropriate distance from the proposed development officers consider that the proposal would not cause adverse harm to the protected tree on site, as such the proposal would accord with Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.Fire safety Policy D12 of the London Plan requires all new development to give regard to fire safety. It is recommended that a condition is imposed to secure the submission of fire safety strategy in order to ensure that the proposed development would accord with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConstructionThe applicant will be bound by the primary legislation under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation such as building regs and the party wall act which includes acceptable hours of construction and control of noise, dust and other activities that could be of a nuisance to neighbouring occupiers during construction and the informatives attached draw the applicants attention to these matters. Any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way. Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwelling house located along Ancaster Crescent. The site is not located in a Conservation Area or Strategic Area of Special Character. ProposalThis application seeks permission for the erection of a single-storey rear extension. Granted planning permission, dated 26 May 2023.Consultations6no. neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals. No representations received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: - The impact of the development on character and appearance;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and- The impact of the development on fire safety. Character & AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The application proposes the construction of a single storey rear extension. This extension would measure approximately 3.3 metres in depth from the rear wall of the dwellinghouse (at its maximum), spanning the full width of the property and would have a pitched roof, with an eaves height of approximately 2.8 metres. This extension broadly conforms to the recommendations of the Residential Design SPD, and would also appear proportionate and subordinate to the dwellinghouse. Officers therefore consider that this element of the proposal would also have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse.  The application also proposes alterations to the roof including change from hip to gable and the construction of a rear dormer extension. Officers note that a similar hip to gable roof extension has been implemented at neighbouring property, No.40 Ancaster Crescent (ref. 13/14336/LDP), as well as No. 38 Ancaster Crescent (ref. 21/01562/HOU). The hip to gable roof extension and rear dormer under consideration in this case would not strictly accord with the guidance set out in the Residential Design SPD, 2013. However, they would be in keeping with the character of the original dwelling and would be similar to those approved works at roof level at No's 38 and 40 Ancaster Crescent. The only material difference between this application and the recently approved scheme (under 23/00780/HOU) is the proposed addition of matching tiles to the side elevation of the loft conversion. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design Guide, 2013.

This would be contrary to the NPPF 2021, Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.(5)	The applicant has not provided a fire safety strategy and the existing access road would not allow sufficient space for an emergency vehicle to safely enter the site, and as such the proposal would not adhere to Policy D12 of the London Plan 2021.16/10002/HOU - Proposed conversion of garage into a habitable room - Withdrawn, 15 Jan 2016.13/10387/HOU - Erection of a single storey detached garage and workshop - Granted planning permission, dated 5 June 2014. ProposalThe application seeks full planning permission for the conversion of the existing detached garage into a 1no. 2-bedroom bungalow with a separate access. Installation of solar panels. Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Housing delivery:-	The standard of accommodation provided;-	The impact upon the character and appearance of the area;-	The impact upon the residential amenity;-	The impact upon highway safety;-	The provision of adequate cycle storage facilities;-	Flood Risk Assessment and drainage; -	The impact on protected trees; -	Fire safety;-	The impact on sustainability;-	The impact on biodiversity; -	Other matters; and,-	The contribution to Community Infrastructure Levy (CIL)Housing DeliveryPolicy CS10 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy, 2012 sets out the Borough's housing targets as defined by the London Plan, 2011.  Policy H1 (Increasing Housing Supply) of The London Plan (2021) sets ten-year targets for net housing completions that each local planning authority should plan for. Table 4.1 sets out the 10 year targets for net housing completions in each London Borough from 2019/20 - 2028/29). The requirement for Kingston is to deliver 9,640 homes in this 10 years period which would equate to 964 net completions per annum.As there is no 5-year housing land supply, paragraph 11 of the NPPF 2021 indicates that planning permission should be granted unless (i) the application of policies in this Framework that protect areas or assets of particular importance provides a clear reason for refusing the development proposed; or (ii) any adverse impacts of doing so significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits, when assessed against policies in this Framework taken as a whole.  These considerations should be given considerable weight in the assessment of any forthcoming planning application.The proposed development would provide a net increase of one single dwelling on site which would constitute a small, albeit positive contribution towards this target. The scheme would utilise the rear amenity space of 34 Somerset Avenue, and as such the site is considered as being garden land and will be assessed on this basis. While there are no specific policies in the London Plan or Core Strategy that prevent development of garden land, there is emphasis on ensuring that new development is sympathetic to the surrounding area, and as such the acceptability of the development in this specific location will be set out in the Character and Design section of this  report. However, with the area being a residential location, the principle of development is considered to be acceptable, subject to compliance with other Development Plan policies. This holds substantial weight in favour of the proposal.Standard of Accommodation                                                                                 Policy D6 (Housing Quality and Standards) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that housing development should be of high quality design and provide adequately sized rooms (as set out in Table 3.1 of the London Plan 2021) with comfortable and functional layouts which are fit for purpose and meet the needs of Londoners without differentiating between tenures. Policy DM13 of the Core Strategy (2012) reiterates the requirement for adequately sized properties. Policy D6 of the London Plan (2021) encourages housing developments to maximise the provision of dual aspect dwellings and normally avoid the provision of single aspect dwellings. Single aspect dwellings should only be provided where it is considered a more appropriate design solution to meet the requirements of Part B of Policy D3 of the London Plan (2021).                                           With regards to private amenity space, Policy D6 of the London Plan (2021) sets out that where there are no higher local standards in the borough Development Plan Documents, a minimum of 5sqm of private outdoor space should be provided for 1-2 person dwellings and an extra 1sqm should be provided for each additional occupant. Policy Guidance 13 of the Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) sets a higher figure of 50sqm of private garden space per family house i.e. three bedrooms.The proposal seeks to provide 1x2 bed dwelling on one floor as a 4 person dwelling. For this sized property, Policy D6 of the London Plan, 2021 would require an internal floorspace of 70sqm, and given that approx. 63.3sqm would be provided as set out in the Design and Access Statement, officers note that it would fall short of the requirements set out in the London Plan. The proposed dwelling would benefit from the required built-in storage space and floor to ceiling height. However, given the proximity of the proposed dwelling to the rear and side boundary treatment, the proposal could be largely considered a single aspect dwelling that is mainly eastern facing with limited resultant outlook and natural daylight/sunlight ingress. Officers also note that the principal window for bedroom 1 would sit in close proximity to the shared boundary to the rear of the site, which would provide limited outlook and privacy given the proximity to the Cricket Club to the west of the site.The proposed dwelling would provide approx. 60sqm of private outdoor amenity space, which would well exceed the requirements of the Residential Design SPD. While there is sufficient amenity space, officers note the changes in levels across the site and, given that the existing dwelling would sit at a higher level, officers consider there to be a loss of privacy, however this could be lessened by appropriate boundary treatment, if planning permission were forthcoming.Having regard to the above, the proposal would not strictly comply with the policy requirements of the London plan, given that the proposal would not provide an adequate quantum of internal floorspace or privacy for all habitable rooms and would not be considered a wholly dual aspect dwelling with resultant poor degree of outlook and natural daylight/sunlight ingress, it is considered that the proposal would result in a substandard form of accommodation. This carries substantial weight against the proposal.Impact upon the Character and Appearance of the AreaPolicy D3 of the London Plan (2021) states that new development should respond to the existing character of a place by identifying the special and valued characteristics of the locality and be of a high quality in terms of design.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officers note that the proposal would utilise the existing detached garden office to the rear of the site. The proposal would not create any additional floor space, but would alter the fenestrations to include additional openings. The proposal would also amend the materiality to appear more in keeping with the existing dwelling, and as such would appear more as an independent dwelling rather than an ancillary outbuilding. Officers note that the proposal would add additional boundary treatment to divide the existing garden land. Given that the subdivision of plots is not a common feature of the form of the immediate surrounding area, and that the proposal would appear less like an ancillary building and more so of an independent dwelling, Officers consider that the proposal would appear more cramped within the existing plot which would not be in keeping with the established character and appearance of the surrounding area.Consistent with the previous assessment, given that backland development is uncharacteristic of the form of the area, the proposal would appear visually out of keeping with the dwellings in the immediate vicinity. This holds substantial weight against the proposal.Impact upon the Residential Amenity of Neighbouring OccupiersPolicy D3 of the London Plan (2021) requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposal would utilise the existing building on site, and therefore it is considered that there would be no overbearing appearance or loss of light/sunlight for the occupants of neighbouring properties. While there would be an intensification of the site for residential use, rather than ancillary use, given that neighbouring properties would be adequately separated from the proposed development, there would be no adverse impact in relation to privacy for the occupants of neighbouring properties. Given that no amenity concerns have been raised, this would be of neutral weight in the balance.Impact upon Highway SafetyParagraph 111 of the NPPF 2021 states that development should only be prevented or refused on transport grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or where the residual cumulative impacts of development are severe. Policies DM9 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy (2012) seek to ensure that new development has regard to local traffic conditions, and does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy T6 of the London Plan (2021) states that car-free developments should be the starting point for all development proposals in places that are well-connected by public transport, with developments elsewhere designed to provide the minimum necessary parking; and an absence of local on-street parking controls should not be a barrier to new development. Table 10.3 then sets out the maximum residential parking standards. The site is located within an area with a PTAL rating of 2 and on-street parking is not restricted within Somerset Avenue. For properties of the size proposed and in this particular location, table 10.3 of the London Plan (2021) sets out a maximum requirement of 0.75 spaces per dwelling. The dwelling would be car-free.It is also noted that the applicant would remove the existing gates to the front of the access road, and add a new gate to the end of the access road. Whilst the applicant does not own this land, the supporting design and access statement sets out that the Facilities Manager at Hollyfield School Sports Ground supports the proposed relocation of the gates and provides email correspondence as evidence to this effect. In this case, subject to the applicant entering into a legal agreement, Officers would be satisfied that the relocation of the gates could be delivered in the way proposed, and would therefore not compromise the ability to provide safe car parking on site in this respect.Officers note that the supporting design and access statement sets out that the applicant would repair the collapsed drain and any road repairs at their own cost. This would also involve the installation of solar powered lights and re-surfaced tarmacadam so as to improve both the vehicular and pedestrian conditions of the access road. This is welcomed and officers would have attached appropriately worded conditions to this effect to secure such improvements.Overall, subject to appropriately worded conditions and the applicant entering into a legal agreement to secure the relocation of the access gate to the neighbouring school sports ground, it is considered that the proposal would not have an adverse impact on pedestrian and highway safety, in general accordance Paragraph 111 of the NPPF, 2021, Policy T4 of the London Plan 2021, and Policies DM9 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012. Provision of Adequate Cycle Storage FacilitiesFigure 10.3 of the London Plan (2021), the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames has higher minimum cycle parking standards as TFL has identified that there is high potential for a switch to cycling within the Borough. Table 10.2 (Minimum cycle parking standards) of the London Plan (2021) sets out minimum cycle parking standards. For a property of the size proposed, there would be a requirement for two cycle spaces. Details of the cycle storage have been provided and this could be secured by an appropriately worded condition if permission were forthcoming. This would hold neutral weight.Flood Risk and DrainagePolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.On the basis that the proposal would ultilise the existing building on site, which has already been raised above ground level, it is considered that the proposal would not increase the possibility of flooding on site or elsewhere. On the basis that the floor level is appropriately above the likely flood level the residential unit should not be subject to flooding. It has not, however, been demonstrated how egress would be made from the proposed dwelling.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation.Sustainability Policy DM1 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires all new residential developments to achieve Code for Sustainable Homes level.Policy DM3 requires development proposals to take into consideration the requirements for climate change adaptation, including through the reduction of potable water consumption.The proposed development would be required to demonstrate that water consumption of 105l could also be achieved - this could be secured via an appropriate condition if planning permission were forthcoming. Other MattersWaste and RecyclingPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy CS9 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 require integrated, well-designed recycling facilities to be incorporated into all new developments.Details of the storage for waste and recycling have been provided on the plans. Whilst further details could be secured via a condition, officers note that inadequate information has been provided in regards to the details of waste collection. Given that the dwelling would be sited approx. 37m from Somerset Avenue, Officers are unable to assess the acceptability of waste arrangements to serve the proposed dwelling, in terms of capacity or siting for its collection by Council operatives. Consultations26no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. No comments received.ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the erection of a single storey log cabin to the rear, with associated concrete base.Site and SurroundingsThe site comprises a semi-detached two-storey (with converted roofspace) residential property on the eastern side of King Charles Road, Surbiton. The application building has been converted into self-contained flats. This application pertains to the private rear garden of Flat 4. The site lies adjacent to, but not within, the Surbiton Hill Conservation Area. The site falls within the Berrylands Road Local Area of Special Character (a non-designated heritage asset).Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance, including heritage assets; -	The Impact upon Residential Amenity; and-	Fire safety assessmentCharacter and Appearance, including Impact upon Heritage AssetsPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals affecting heritage assets, and their settings, should conserve their significance, by being sympathetic to the assets' significance and appreciation within their surroundings. The cumulative impacts of incremental change from development on heritage assets and their settings should also be actively managed. Development proposals should avoid harm and identify enhancement opportunities by integrating heritage considerations early on in the design process.At the local level, Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 set out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.At paragraph 203 of the NPPF, the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining the application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement will be required having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Accordingly, the Core Strategy states the Council's intention to protect the primarily suburban character of the Borough, its existing buildings and areas of high quality and historic interest from inappropriate development. The Council will seek opportunities for sensitive enhancement in these areas and in areas of poorer environmental quality, where character has been eroded or needs improving. The assessment of development proposals will be guided by the Borough Character Study and the Residential Design SPD, ensuring that new development:-	Recognises distinctive local features and character-	Has regard to the historic and natural environment-	Helps enhance locally distinctive places of high architectural and urban design quality-	Accords with neighbourhood "strategies for delivery" set out under "Character, Design and Heritage"-	Relates well and connects to its surroundingsPolicy Guidance 41 (Outbuildings) is applicable to the application. The SPD outlines that where they are used as ancillary to the use of the existing house (sheds, greenhouses, hobby rooms or storerooms) that planning permission is generally not required. In this case, the existing outbuilding would be for the use of a gym and a bathroom and as such, will require planning permission.In terms of scale and design, the guidance advises that in general outbuildings should be positioned as far away as possible from any shared boundaries to stop overshadowing of neighbouring properties; should not be built forward of the established building line; should relate well to the design of the existing house; generally be built of similar materials to the existing house; and not affect the existing parking provision of the development and any parking lost as a result of the outbuilding should be replaced on site. This planning application pertains to Flat 4 which is afforded a private rear garden to the rear of the building.In terms of scale, the outbuilding is considered to appear as an appropriate addition to the site and host property by way of its modest height of 2.4m (to eaves), 3.3m (to its pitch). The outbuilding would occupy approximately just under half of the width of the plot (at approximately 4m) and would have a depth of 5m. Officers acknowledge that it would be screened on three sides by boundary treatment (fencing) to a height of 1.8m and, this, together with the proposed siting inset at a distance of approximately 1m from the northern and eastern side boundaries and 5m from the southern side boundary, means the outbuilding is appropriately positioned so as not to appear overly obtrusive.In terms of design, the proposed use of painted timber to the front, rear and two side external walls, grey shingle tiles for the roof and double-glazed window and door frames is considered to be acceptable for such type of garden structure. More than 50% of the amenity space will remain and, therefore, it is not found that this will have a detrimental impact on the amenity and character of the property. As a result, the proposed development would not detract from the character and appearance of the host property or the wide area and therefore would accord with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LFD Core Strategy April 2012. Similarly, the proposal is considered to have a neutral impact upon the non-designated heritage asset of Berrylands Road Local Area of Special Character, and accord with the objectives of Policy DM12 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012 in this regard.Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.1no. entrance door and 2no. windows are proposed to the front elevation of the outbuilding (facing south) set a distance of approximately 5m from the side boundary fencing. 1no. side facing window is proposed to the western side elevation (facing towards the rear of No. 27 King Charles Road). The window would be at a distance of 12m from the rear of No. 27 King Charles Road. On balance, it is not considered that the proposals would give rise to materially harmful overlooking or loss of privacy. The proposed windows are not considered to pose impacts on neighbouring amenity.Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012).Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling located within the Coombe Hill Conservation Area and Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. The trees situated within the application site are subject to Tree Preservation Order. Proposal Erection of outbuilding, climbing frame and swing to rear, changes to ground floor side fenestration, increase to first floor front balcony depth, alterations to front dormer roof. Retrospective application for installation of 4nos. air conditioning units on the first floor and landscaping.ConsultationsMaldens And Coombe Neighbourhood Conservation Areas Advisory Committee - objects to the proposal:Reason for objection: Relatively minor alterations (adding only 7m2) and landscaping - using materials replicating on site or in use in neighbouring properties. The proposed use of uPVC door should be replaced by a door of a more sympathetic material. Objection unless revised as above. Tree Officer - no objection5 properties were notified of the proposal. Four representations have been received objecting to the proposal, with comments summarised as follows:- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inadequate landscaping/means of enclosure- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/Sunlight - Noise- Privacy- The submitted plans don't show the current building status, the property boundaries have been drawn incorrectly- Right of Light- Noise and environmental pollution during construction works- raised ground level would damage the adjoining property (impact on foundations and its structural integrity, damp issues)- installation of AC units raises noise issues, visual impact and energy efficiency concerns- Effects on treesOfficer response: Any matters controlled under non-planning laws (such as right to light), building regulations or problems arising from the construction period are not material planning considerations and they cannot be included within the assessment.Any other concerns raised with the written representations will be addressed with this report.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,-The impact of the development on the Heritage Assets; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on the protected trees; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note differences in ground level at Ridge House as per available maps (RBK Lidar Contour). The front of the application site starts at the level of 32m and slopes down towards the rear to 28m.The submitted proposed plans and Design and Access Statement suggest that the ground levels to the rear were raised by 400mm and the new raised patio area of 300mm has been erected as part of the retrospective works. The proposed ground floor drawing (36-062) shows a 'new level patio area' to the front of the property. It is considered that insufficient information with regards to the pre-existing and existing (as the raised ground levels form the retrospective part of the proposal) ground levels in relation to all the adjoining properties was submitted to demonstrate that the raised ground levels and the raised patio area would not have an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the host dwelling and the surrounding area. As the proposed ground levels and raised patio levels would trigger alterations to boundary treatment and given its scale, on balance, this element of the proposal is likely to adversely affect the character of the host dwelling and the surrounding area. The proposed outbuilding would be approximately 2.5m high and situated on the raised patio area in the north-east corner of the property. While the erection of an outbuilding with a flat roof of the total height of approximately 2.5m would generally fall within the permitted development rights, in this case the proposed/retrospective works include raised ground levels and raised patio area and therefore would not benefit from this 'fallback' position. The proposed climbing frame (approximately 2.75m high) situated along the east common boundary and on the raised ground level, given its siting and the proposed scale, is considered to be acceptable from the design point of view. It is noted that  Maldens and Coombe Neighbourhood Conservation Areas Advisory Committee raised objection to the proposed alterations to fenestration in terms of the proposed materials. The new UPVC sliding door to the side elevation at the ground floor level should be finished in more sympathetic materials. The proposed increase of the depth of the front balcony by approximately 300mm, given its siting is considered to be acceptable and in-keeping with the host dwelling.With regards to the proposed alterations to the front rear dormer to the office outbuilding, the proposed increase in width and height of the dormer, given its siting, scale, mass and bulk is considered to be acceptable although not in strict accordance with Policy Guidance 39 of the Council's Residential Design SPD.It is considered that the proposed and existing heat pump air conditioning units given their scale and siting are considered to be acceptable from the character and appearance perspective. Overall, it is considered that insufficient information was submitted in relation to the retrospective and significant changes to the ground levels to demonstrate, on balance, that this element of the proposal would not not have an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the host dwelling and the surrounding area.Heritage AssetsSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                  In determining planning applications which affect heritage assets, Paragraph  192 of the NPPF 2019 requires local planning authorities to take account of: the desirability of sustaining and enhancing the significance of heritage assets and putting them to viable uses consistent with their conservation; the positive contribution that conservation of heritage assets can make to sustainable communities including their economic vitality; and the desirability of new development making a positive contribution to local character and distinctiveness.                                                                                                                     Paragraph 193 of NPPF 2019 states that when considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the assets conservation, irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts of substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.                                              Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer comment:  The application falls within the Coombe Hill Conservation Area. The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as: the estate and hinterland to the demolished Coombe Warren, containing several mid 19th century properties by architect George Devey and other large interesting 20th century houses in a spacious landscaped setting, adjoining Coombe Hill Golf Course.The application property is not listed or locally listed, but nonetheless contributes positively to the conservation area. As per the paragraph above, Officers raise concerns in relation to the proposed changes to the ground levels, it is likely that this element of the proposal would not be appropriate for the property located within a conservation area. Furthermore, the Conservation Areas Advisory Committee raised concerns with regards to the proposed materials for the sliding door at the ground floor level in the side elevation, that should be more appropriate for properties located in conservation areas. Having regard to the above, Officers conclude that it has not been demonstrated that the proposal would not result in any harm to the conservation area and would preserve its significance.  Non-Designated Heritage AssetsParagraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Paragraph 203 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.The application property falls within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character, which is a non-designated heritage asset. As stated above Officers consider that the proposed development is likely to result in an adverse impact to the host property and therefore have an unacceptable impact on the character and appearance of the wider area. It follows that Officers consider that the proposed development would  result in harm to the significance of this LASC.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is considered that the proposed alterations to fenestration, to the front balcony and front roof dormer, given its scale and siting would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers at the adjoining properties. With regards to the proposed increase in ground levels, provision of raised patio area and the climbing frame, given the difference in ground levels, it has not been demonstrated that it would not adversely affect the amenities of the adjoining occupiers in terms of an overbearing appearance, undue overlooking and loss of privacy. While the installation of air conditioning units is considerd to be acceptable, additional details of the level of noise would be secure via condition. It is further noted that the Environmental Protection Act (1990) provides controls to the Council in the event that any noise should occur that could constitute a statutory nuisance. Protected TreesPolicy G7 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. If planning permission is granted that necessitates the removal of trees, there should be adequate replacement. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 expects new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders (TPOs) are not adversely affected.It is noted that the Council's Tree Officer raised no objection to the proposal. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

While this is, in effect, a fresh application for the entire development, the principle of the development has nevertheless already been established.On such an application, the local planning authority may only consider the conditions subject to which permission should be granted. It would therefore be unnecessary and unreasonable to revisit every issue which was relevant to the determination of the original application.In assessing the application, officers are mindful of any changes in planning policy or site circumstances since the grant of the original permission.It is acknowledged that there is no statutory definition of a minor material amendment (MMA) although the Planning Practice Guidance (PPG) explains that a MMA is 'likely to include any amendment where its scale and/or nature results in a development which is not substantially different from the one which has been approved'.Impact upon Character and Appearance of the Area (including heritage assets)Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed changes submitted under this application to the approved permission comprise of the change to the colour of roof tiles to grey and window frames to grey. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed changes would not create any material loss of amenity or privacy beyond that assessed under the original application. Overall, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties.Conclusion/Planning BalanceUnder the provisions of s.73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, the proposed amendments to Condition 1 (Approved Plans) of Planning Permission reference 23/00911/HOU are considered to maintain appropriate good quality design and would not result in material difference or material harm in terms of character and appearance of the proposed development, nor in terms of impacts upon neighbouring amenity. The proposals are considered to comply with Policy D3 of the London Plan, 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames LDF Core Strategy, April 2012.  RECOMMENDATIONGrant planning permission.
